title: Remember Natzweiler-Struthof
intro_text: Natzweiler in occupied Alsace prefecture was the only concentration camp of the Third Reich on French territory. From May 1941, at least 52,000 people from Poland, the USSR, France and throughout Europe were deported and brought to either the main camp at "the Struthof" or to one of the many affiliated satellite camps in Hesse, Baden and Württemberg. 22,000 of them died directly in these camps, from ill-treatment by the SS, from exhaustion or diseases resulting from the hard work and bad conditions in the quarries, from human experiments with poison gas or typhus, from starvation or freezing, from torture, shooting, hanging, lethal injections or gasification. It is not known to date how many prisoners lost their lives during the mass executions and the death marches after the evacuation of the camp, at the approach of the Allied forces.
unterschrift: Laying flowers at the 70th anniversary day, Commemorative Ceremony of Remembrance, Natzweiler, Image: Club sportif et artistique de la défense de Mutzig-Gresswiller-Molsheim
body_text: All the killings, the suffering and the torture served to act out the sadism of the SS, justified on basis of the ethno-racialist propaganda derogatory of all non-"genuinely" German people, to develop and consolidate the Nazi terror system in Germany and Europe, and to fulfill the narcissistic megalomania of Adolf Hitler and his "General Building Inspector for the Reich Capital", Albert Speer, who wanted to build a "World Capital Germania" and a "German Stadium" from pink granite for their supposedly "Thousand Year Reich".
unterschrift2: Dissection room, Natzweiler concentration camp, Sculpture "Alignment", Image: Michaël Verry
body2_text: Since 1945, the survivors of Natzweiler banded together in groups of friends, to keep alive the memories of those who died in the camp at regular ceremonies. In 1960 an official memorial was inaugurated in honor of the martyrs and heroes of the deportations by President Charles de Gaulle. This was followed in 1965 by a first museum and in 2005 by the opening of the European Center for Deported Resistance Fighters (CERD) by President Jacques Chirac, built on the grounds of the former concentration camp. At the center, visitors are introduced to the history of the German occupation and the system of concentration camps, as well as to the French and European resistance, and reminded of people like General Charles Delestraint, who had the courage to take the fight to the overpowering fascism and Nazism, before they enter the memorial and the camp barracks.
unterschrift3: Sculpture "Nevertheless", Natzweiler concentration camp, Image: Michaël Verry
